text: hello everyone
this video will provide a brief
walkthrough of the aws certificate
manager private ca console and we will
also cover the initial setup of a new
private certificate authority or ca but
first let's talk a little bit about the
benefits of using this service
acm private ca provides you an easy and
secure way to create a private ca and
use it to create and manage your private
certificates
acm private ca is secured with aws
managed hardware security modules or
hsms that adhere to fips 140-2 security
standards to securely store the keys for
your private ca
administrators can control access to the
service using aws identity and access
management policies and you can even
share a ca using aws resource access
manager to decrease the costs of
managing cas in multiple aws accounts
you can audit private ca activity using
adbs cloudtrail logging and monitoring
service
managing a public key infrastructure in
your own data center can be expensive
and requires a high level of technical
expertise
with acm private ca adbs manages the
infrastructure on your behalf and
greatly reduces the complexity involved
in managing private certificates
okay now let's take a look at how this
works in the adbs console
from the adbs console we'll start by
selecting the abs certificate manager
service
now we're presented with the option to
request a public certificate or create a
private ca
we'll click the create a private ca
option on the right hand side
next we're shown a list of cas we've
created if any
you can see that i already have several
in this account
on the right hand side
we can see the status of the ca
is it active or disabled or deleted what
type of ca is it root or subordinate
you can also view when it was created
when it expires and some of the x.509
attributes associated with the ca upon
creation
you can also see the ca certificate
validity the certificate issued by the
root ca
you can view the revocation information
associated with the ca
either using certificate verification
lists or online certificate status
protocol or ocsp
on the top right we can see there is an
option to create a new ca
let's click this to create a new
certificate authority
we can choose to create a root ca or a
subordinate ca
some customers choose to host their root
ca and aws others only host their
subordinate cas like intermediate cas or
issuing cas in aws and leave their root
ca on-prem
but for now we'll create a root ca that
will act as the top of our chain of
trust
next we'll need to enter some
information that identifies the
certificate including the country and
the province or locality
arguably most important is the common
name this identifies the ca
note that these fields cannot be changed
after creating the ca
for now
we'll just enter the organization name
and a common name
[Music]
the next option we are presented with is
to select the key algorithm associated
with the certificate key pair
the default value is rsa 2048
however some customers may have
requirements or use cases that drive
them to use larger key links for rsa or
elliptic curve algorithms which are also
supported
most customers tend to use rsa but
elliptic curve algorithms are often used
for use cases such as iot devices and
sensors as elliptic curve algorithms
require less computing power than rsa
and are therefore more suitable for
small devices with limited processing
power
next we can configure revocation options

customers who want to use private

ability to automatically renew
certificates the acm provides
next review the information we've
entered and options we've selected and
create the ca

to demystify this process what we're
really doing here is creating a
certificate signing request or csr
and using the newly created root ca's
private key to cryptographically sign
the csr
this creates the root ca certificate
that will be used by the ca to sign
other ca certificates for intermediate
or issuing cas
here we can pick a validity value and
validity type in this case 10 years and

algorithm of sha-256 with rsa
now we'll click next

to install the root ca certificate
